SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, identifying words that impact the meaning in a text.
Content: What is the meaning of “pecked” in paragraph 2?

A.Choice: poked

B.Choice: ran from

C.Choice: marched to

D.Choice: tossed

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, identifying words that impact the meaning in a text.
Content: What is the meaning of “latch” in paragraph 2?

A.Choice: side

B.Choice: fence

C.Choice: lock

D.Choice: bottom

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: What did Rhode Island Red do after he got out of his cage?

A.Choice: He rode with the animals on the roller coaster.

B.Choice: He put all of the animals in their cages.

C.Choice: He chased the animals to the midway.

D.Choice: He let the other animals out of their cages.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: How did the boy get all the animals back in their cages?

A.Choice: He chased after each one to get them to run into their cages.

B.Choice: He shook a pail of oats while yelling at the animals to get back in their cages.

C.Choice: He dropped a trail of oats behind him so the animals would follow him to their cages.

D.Choice: He grabbed Rhode Island Red first and then scared all the other animals to their cages.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Which word describes the boy in the text?

A.Choice: clever

B.Choice: scared

C.Choice: unusual

D.Choice: useless

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Use both parts of this text to answer this question.
Why is Rhode Island Red so pleased with himself at the end of the text?

A.Choice: He gets the boy to feed all the animals and let them out of their cages.

B.Choice: He gets all the animals back into their cages without anyone else's help.

C.Choice: He is happy to be in his cage with a long drink and some food.

D.Choice: He is happy that he let the animals out of their cages so they could have some fun.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Use both parts of this text to answer this question.
What is one way that Rhode Island Red and the boy are alike?

A.Choice: They both lead the animals.

B.Choice: They both chase the animals.

C.Choice: They both feed the animals.

D.Choice: They both catch the animals.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Use both parts of this text to answer this question.
Which statement from the text shows that Rhode Island Red is proud?

A.Choice: “And in the middle of the poultry tent sat Rhode Island Red, the rooster.”

B.Choice: “One morning, Red pecked at the latch on his cage.”

C.Choice: “Rhode Island Red headed straight for the goose tent.”

D.Choice: “But Rhode Island Red just drank a long drink, fluffed up his feathers, and crowed, 'R-r-r-r-roooo!'”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: What is the meaning of “inspired” in paragraph 4?

A.Choice: changed

B.Choice: started

C.Choice: finished

D.Choice: used

A.Choice: drawing pictures

B.Choice: creating a title

C.Choice: getting started

D.Choice: reading a book

Content: What is the meaning of “portrait” in paragraph 6?

A.Choice: lesson

B.Choice: picture

C.Choice: report

D.Choice: story

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: According to the text, why does the cat have a bell on its collar?

A.Choice: The bell warns the birds.

B.Choice: The bell makes a nice sound.

C.Choice: The bell is pretty.

D.Choice: The bell is interesting.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Describe how the author connects ideas between sentences and paragraphs to support specific points in a text.
Content: How does the author connect the writing steps in paragraphs 10 and 11?

A.Choice: by contrasting two different styles for writing books

B.Choice: by giving a step-by-step process for publishing a book

C.Choice: by comparing the writing steps for two kinds of books

D.Choice: by giving a chronological order for beginning a book

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Describe how the author connects ideas between sentences and paragraphs to support specific points in a text.
Content: How does the author connect the ideas in paragraphs 12 and 13?

A.Choice: by listing important events that have occurred in the author's life

B.Choice: by explaining the different parts of the book that have to be made

C.Choice: by describing how the author gets ideas when they just will not come

D.Choice: by comparing the rhythm of the text when read aloud to how it looks on paper

SubTopics: Distinguish the literal and nonliteral meanings of words and phrases in context.
Content: What is the meaning of the phrase “right under your nose” in paragraph 16?

A.Choice: inside a person

B.Choice: on a person's face

C.Choice: read by a person

D.Choice: in front of a person

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: Use both parts of this text to answer this question.
Which statement by the author supports the main idea?

A.Choice: “The books I made needed text, so I began writing words to go with my art.”

B.Choice: “Getting a good idea for a book is the hardest thing for me, but also the most fun.”

C.Choice: “I like to write out rough story ideas for my books, then make thumbnail sketches.”

D.Choice: “I like to read the text out loud and listen to the rhythm of the words.”

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Why was Billy in a hurry?

A.Choice: He was looking for Grandfather Frog.

B.Choice: He was getting careless in his old age.

C.Choice: He was going to eat breakfast.

D.Choice: He was looking for Little Joe Otter.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Why was Grandfather Frog sleeping?

A.Choice: He was hot.

B.Choice: He is old.

C.Choice: He had just eaten.

D.Choice: He had been sick.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Why does Jerry laugh when he sees Grandfather Frog?

A.Choice: Grandfather Frog is jumping on the lily pads.

B.Choice: Grandfather Frog has part of a fly sticking out of his mouth.

C.Choice: Grandfather Frog has singing lessons after breakfast with his friends.

D.Choice: Grandfather Frog is dancing because he is happy to see Jerry.

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.

C.Choice: attacked

D.Choice: entered

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Why did Grandfather Frog close his eyes to look just as he did when he was asleep?

A.Choice: to play a joke on Billy

B.Choice: to get back to his nap

C.Choice: to be a friend to Jerry

D.Choice: to finish eating the fly

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, identifying words that impact the meaning in a text.
Content: What is the meaning of “splendid” in paragraph 17?

A.Choice: fast

B.Choice: great

C.Choice: safe

D.Choice: usual

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Use both parts of this text to answer this question.
Which detail from the text supports that Grandfather Frog was scared when Jerry pounded the water with his tail?

A.Choice: “'The idea of going to sleep right out in plain sight like that!'”

B.Choice: “He was just about to make a frightened plunge into the Smiling Pool when he saw Jerry.”

C.Choice: “'I wasn't asleep!' protested Grandfather Frog indignantly.”

D.Choice: “'Don't you think it a rather dangerous plan to think so long with your eyes closed?' asked Jerry.”

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Use both parts of this text to answer this question.
How does Jerry's climb to the top of his house contribute to the rest of the text?

A.Choice: He realizes that he wants to take a nap.

B.Choice: He knows that he wants to go fishing.

C.Choice: He knows where to find Longlegs the Blue Heron.

D.Choice: He realizes why Billy Mink is in such a hurry.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: According to the text, which choice describes a beaver's tail?

A.Choice: It is three feet long and weighs forty or fifty pounds.

B.Choice: It has small scales similar to those of a fish.

C.Choice: It is covered with shiny, brown fur.

D.Choice: It looks like a hairy rudder on a boat.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.

B.Choice: piling stones and mud on top

C.Choice: watching which way the stream runs

D.Choice: checking to see if it is strong and safe

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Describe how the author connects ideas between sentences and paragraphs to support specific points in a text.
Content: What is the connection between paragraphs 5 and 6?

A.Choice: They present a problem and offer a solution.

B.Choice: They explain a cause-effect relationship.

C.Choice: They present a sequence for building.

D.Choice: They compare habits of wise beavers.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Why do beavers carefully inspect a dam after building it?

A.Choice: Beavers need to build a bridge to get across the stream.

B.Choice: Beavers know that water will wash away a weak dam.

C.Choice: Beavers want to find the best place to build a house or village.

D.Choice: Beavers make the walls of their houses with big sticks.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Describe how the author connects ideas between sentences and paragraphs to support specific points in a text.
Content: How are paragraphs 10 and 11 connected?

A.Choice: Both compare the two ways that beavers build dams.

B.Choice: Both describe the differences between a dam and a pond.

C.Choice: Paragraph 10 presents a problem, and paragraph 11 describes a solution.

D.Choice: Paragraph 10 shows a result of the unusual situation in paragraph 11.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: Use both parts of this text to answer this question.
Which detail from the text supports the main idea?

A.Choice: “A beaver is a wild animal about three feet in length.”

B.Choice: “They first gather together a number of sticks and logs.”

C.Choice: “No beaver ever thinks of living alone.”

D.Choice: “Each beaver has his fixed place on the floor.”

D.Choice: expected

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Why did the rock climbers end their climb early?

A.Choice: The weather was bad.

B.Choice: The group was bored.

C.Choice: The dog was tired.

D.Choice: The dog was sick.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: According to the text, what caused the climbers to fall down the mountain?

A.Choice: They were very tired.

B.Choice: The mountain was rocky.

C.Choice: It was getting dark.

D.Choice: The mountain was slippery.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Describe how the author connects ideas between sentences and paragraphs to support specific points in a text.
Content: How does the author connect the point that the climb was very dangerous in paragraphs 5 and 6?

A.Choice: The information in paragraph 6 is a result of the action in paragraph 5.

B.Choice: The ideas in paragraphs 5 and 6 compare the different climbers.

C.Choice: Paragraphs 5 and 6 describe the path the climbers took.

D.Choice: Paragraph 5 lists the steps needed for paragraph 6.

SubTopics: Distinguish the literal and nonliteral meanings of words and phrases in context.

A.Choice: to look at an idea one believes in

B.Choice: to admit that something is true

C.Choice: to escape from danger

D.Choice: to learn something new

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: According to the text, what is the relationship between the climbers petting Velvet's fur and Velvet licking them?

A.Choice: Both dried the climbers.

B.Choice: Both scared the climbers.

C.Choice: Both calmed the climbers.

D.Choice: Both warmed the climbers.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: Use both parts of this text to answer this question.
What is the main idea of the text?

A.Choice: Mount Hood can be a dangerous place.

B.Choice: Mount Hood is popular for rock climbing.

C.Choice: A dog helps a group of rock climbers.

D.Choice: A group of teachers goes rock climbing.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: Use both parts of this text to answer this question.
Which statement from the text supports the main idea?

A.Choice: “They had no idea a German shepherd named Velvet would help save their lives.”

B.Choice: “On Sunday, the weather took a turn for the worse.”

C.Choice: “They hiked for miles to try to make it down the mountainside.”

D.Choice: “The rescue team found the climbers with Velvet in White River Canyon at about 7,400 feet.”
